page.title: 09FARMING - 2
page.content:
{FARMING (2) {fEARON'S FARM On Sunday the 20th of ctober 1985 I went to Mr. Fearon's farm. I asked him a few questions. Mr. Fearon's family have farmed there for three generations. He keeps dairy cattle. He sells off the old ones and the bull calves. The rest are kept for milking. His farm is 121 acres. The most important crop is silage, grown for winter food for the cows. Most of the farm machinery is connected with silage cutting, collecting and storage. The cows are Friesians. The disorders Mr. Fearon has to look out for most are milk fever and grass staggers.
{Reported by Mark Dennis, aged 9. {
